name: I'm Leaving You [This Lonesome Song]
comments: "I"m Leaving You" (aka I'm Leaving You This Lonesome Song) was written and recorded by the Delmore Brothers in 1933.  In 1963, Mike Seeger made a field recording of Sara and Maybelle Carter singing the song and their version was eventually released in 1997.  Many of the modern performers of this song know it from the Carters' version so it's often incorrectly attributed to the Carter Family on their releases.

name: Babies in the Mill
comments: Children of the poor in America, as elsewhere, were an important source of cheap labor in mines, quarries, in the manufacture of glass, candy, matches, rope, canned goods, garments, textiles, tobacco products, and much more. This song was written by Dorsey Dixon in the 1960s, recounting the child labor he had known in earlier years of mill work.

name: A Dream [Poem]
comments: "A Dream" is a poem published in the August 27, 1892 Salvation Army's War Cry publication.  Shadduck was an officer in the Salvation Army at the time based in Hannibal, Missouri. Shaddock published the poem under the nom de plume, "Nomad of Hannibal, Missouri". His text became the lyrics to the song now known as The Great Judgement Morning , though it wasn't until 1913 until his actual name appeared in a hymnal.

name: I Like Molasses
comments: aka "Lasses". Novelty song about the singer liking to eat molasses.  Likely first recorded by Hank Penny on July 4, 1939 and released on a Feb 1940 Vocalion single as "I Like Molasses".  Penny's release credited someone named "Lair" as songwriter. Roy Acuff sang the exact same song at the Grand Old Opry on December 13, 1941 (but never released his rendition).  Arthur "Guitar Boogie" Smith recorded and released his version in 1947 as "Lasses" and credited himself, but his version had the exact same lyrics.  Penny re-recorded his song in 1951 and this time "Lair" isn't credited, there is just an arrangement credit to a "Ty Tobias". Smith re-recorded his song as well in 1964 as "I Like 'Lasses".  However, only Arthur Smith copyrighted his version and the song is always associated with him, but it seems unlikely that he wrote it given that Penny's first recording predated his by eight years. NOTE: There was another molasses song called "Molasses, Molasses (It's Icky Sticky Goo)" that was a hit for Teresa Brewer in 1950 and recorded by a number of other artists that year.  There is another song called "Black Strap Molasses" and one called "Molasses Strap Blues", but they are all distinctly different.

It chronicles Charles Lindbergh's famous pioneer solo-flight across the Atlantic Ocean in the Spirit of St. Louis. The song was an overnight hit being released immediately on the heels of Lindbergh's safe landing.

name: The Trooper and the Maid / The Light Dragoon
comments: ""The Light (or Bold) Dragoon" or "The Trooper and the Maid" [Roud 162; Child 299; G/D 7:1470 ; Ballad Index C299; trad.] dates back to at least the 1820s in Scottish texts. The story is pretty much the same across all versions, although the ending is sometimes different. The young lady in Harry List's song seems quite happy with the proceedings, but in most other versions she asks the trooper when they are to be married, only to be answered with traditional put-offs such as “When cockle shells grow silver bells”, or “When apple-trees grow in the sea”.

name: Richmond Is a Hard Road to Travel
comments: "Richmond is a Hard Road to Travel" is a well-known Confederate song of the American Civil War, based on the song "Jordan is a Hard Road to Travel" by Daniel Decatur Emmett. It was popular with the Confederate troops in the east, as it made fun of Union commanders in the first two years of the war. The song was penned by the editor of the Southern Literary Messenger, John Reuben Thompson, in 1863. Each stanza mentions a separate campaign, starting with First Battle of Bull Run, the Valley Campaign, the Battle of Drewry's Bluff, the Peninsula Campaign, the Battle of Cedar Mountain, the Second Battle of Bull Run, and the Battle of Fredericksburg.
adapted_from: Jordan Is a Hard Road to Travel written by Dan Emmett

name: Grafted into the Army
comments: Henry Clay Work, was a composer during the civil war era who was born in Connecticut. His father was very involved in the anti-slavery movement as well as the Underground Railroad. Work used his music as a way to make statements and sentiments about the war. He wrote abolitionist songs, but also made some comedic music. In 1862, as a response to the draft, Work wrote the song “Grafted into the Army.” During this time, all men were drafted into the army unless they sent a substitute for themselves or could pay a three hundred dollar exemption fee. The song “Grafted into the Army,” is sang from the perspective of a mother who learns that her youngest and only surviving son has been drafted into the army. The word “grafted” is used by Work to emphasize the idea that money is able to substitute for the wealthy men who could have potentially enlisted.

name: Faith of Our Fathers
comments: "Faith of our Fathers" is a Catholic hymn, written in 1849 by Englishman Frederick William Faber in memory of the Catholic martyrs from the time of the establishment of the Church of England by Henry VIII and Elizabeth. Faber wrote two versions of the hymn: with seven stanzas for Ireland and with four for England. The Irish version was sung at hurling matches until the 1960s. Faber's hymn was later edited by unknown parties to make it more appealing to non-Catholics and an additional refrain was added. James G. Walton added these revisions when he set the text to a tune by Englishman Henri F. Hemy called St. Catherine.  Walton must have registered this arrangement as his creation for many performances today credit Walton.  In the UK it is usually sung to the traditional tune Sawston; in the US, Hemy's St. Catherine tune is more commonly used.

name: Somebody's Darling
comments: Somebody’s Darling, was originally a poem written by Marie Ravenel de LaCoste, a nurse (and a poet) of Savannah, Georgia. The poem first appeared in print in 1864. Miss de LaCoste took her poem to Hermann L Schreiner of J. C. Schreiner & Son music firm of Savannah requesting that it be turned into a song. Schreiner forwarded the piece and the request to John Hill Hewitt who set the text to music the same year. Opening line "Into the ward of the clean white-washed halls, Where the dead slept and the dying lay.."
adapted_from: Somebody's Darling [Poem] written by Marie Ravenel de la Coste

American broadsides of the song date back to around 1830. [Verse One of the Jackaroe or There Was a Wealthy Merchant variants] There was a wealthy merchant, in London he did dwell. He had a beautiful daughter, the truth to you I'll tell. She had sweethearts a-plenty and men of high degree But none but Jack the sailor her true love ere could be.

name: Lord Thomas and Fair Annet / Eleanor

Regional and printed variations of the ballad are known by many titles, including "Fair Eleanor", "Lord Thomas and Fair Ellender", "Fair Ellen and the Brown Girl", "Lord Thomas's Wedding", "The Brown Bride", and others. Related English ballads which share stanza composition as well as narratives of heartbreak-induced death include Fair Margaret and Sweet William and Lord Lovel.

Parker in 1890.  The song lyrics are brief.  The original singing was straightforward but the black gospel versions sing the exact same lyrics at a very slow, drawn out pace for emphasis and sound almost unrelated. [Verse One] The day is past and gone, The evening shades appear; O may we all remember well The night of death draws near.

name: The Farmer's Curst Wife
comments: The Farmer's Curst Wife is Child ballad number 278.  The lyrics of the ballad are sometimes sung to the melody of the song Lillibullero. Synopsis - A farmer has a wife who causes him stress. One day, the Devil takes her away to Hell. In Hell, the wife commits violent acts. She makes life in hell so bad for the Devil that he brings her back to her husband. On August 7, 1932 Arthur Kyle Davis Jr. made a field recording of Texas Gladden singing an early version of this song ("Two Little Devils") in Roanoke County, Virginia. On August 15, 1932 Arthur Kyle Davis Jr. made another field recording of Horton Barker singing an early version in Chilhowie, Smyth County, Virginia.

name: El cheque en blanco
comments: Emma, the author tells about the song: “I did it for personal revenge. When I sang it, I told the gentlemen that it was not for everyone, but for one in particular, one who made a bad move on me, and I charged him! I sing the rest to the others. " "That composition was not going to make it known, but it came out and it was a bomb. It is smart; they came to call it the women's hymn. It was against a man who ran the racetrack; He has already died, his name was Justo Fernández. It hurt when he received the song, but later he presumed that I had made it for him. He cheated me. He said he wanted to marry me, that he was single and who knows what. Later I learned that it was not true, that he was married and had children. Why do they play with one like that? Why is one not from their environment? Do you think you can do everything for your money? Well, no! Later he became a friend of us, but when I sang it to him, he did take out his gun and put it on my back; He told me: "I'm going to kill you, because I wouldn't even allow my mother to tell me what you're saying!"

name: I'm the Singer, You're the Song
Little Stream of Whiskey
comments: Song first recorded by Burnett & Rutherford in November 1926.  It's uncertain who wrote these lyrics as they are hodgepodge from other traditionals.  The first verse is lifted directly from Kelly Harrell's April 1926 "George Collins" rendition named Dying Hobo . [Verse One] A way out west on a water tank One cold December day An' in the empty car box A dying hobo laid After the first verse, "Little Stream of Whiskey" has no relation to Harrell's "Dying Hobo", and has zero relation to the actual "George Collins" song. However, Little Stream of Whiskey is often referred to as Dying Hobo (hence the confusion attributing the original to Kelly Harrell). The Burnett and Rutherford tune (which contains most of the verses that Doc Watson and others later sang) is all about the dying hobo and his last words to his "partner hobo" about going to the place where he "will not have to work at all", and where "a little stream of whiskey is flowing from the rocks". Though he leaves word for his "girl in Danville, not to worry at all". This song has a few lyrics in common with Jimmie Rodgers' "Hobo Bill's Last Ride" (attributed to Waldo O'Neal), but the latter mentions nobody else present at the scene. "Little Stream" is also related to the "Big Rock Candy Mountain" family of songs, in which the hobo describes his paradise.

name: Loving You Could Never Be Better

comments: Traditonal African-American work song. In May 1939, Herbert Halpert made a field recording of Mary James, a prisoner at the State Penitentiary in Parchman, Mississippi, singing "Go 'Way Devil, Leave Me Alone". On May 21, 1939, John Lomax made a field recording of Frances Anderson, a prisoner at the Cummins State Farm, Women's Camp in Gould Arkansas, singing "Oh Go 'Way, Devil, an' Leave Me 'Lone". The Lomax recording doesn't appear to have been commercially released, but can be heard HERE .

name: The Bonnie Lass of Fyvie / Pretty Peggy-O
comments: [Roud 545; G/D 1:84; Ballad Index SBoA020; Bodleian Roud 545; Wiltshire 971; trad.]. The Bonnie Lass o' Fyvie is a traditional Scottish folk song about a thwarted romance between a soldier and a girl. There is no strict version of the lyrics and the song has multiple variants including Handoms Polly-O, Peggy-O, Fennario, and The Maid of Fife.  The Americanized variant is usually called "Peggy-O". [Verse One - Bonnie Lass of Fyvie] There once was a troop o' Irish dragoons Cam marching doon through Fyvie-o And the captain's fa'en in love wi' a very bonnie lass And her name it was ca'd pretty Peggy-o

name: Stern Old Bachelor
comments: Traditional song related to the 1860 song, "I'm a Jolly Bachelor." The lyrics to the song "The Old Bachelor" were first referenced in print in the 1887 newspaper "Dighton Republic" in Kansas. Chubby Parker first recorded this song in 1927. The Carter Family covered it in 1938 and A.P. Carter registered it as his own work so the song is often incorrectly assumed to be a Carter Family original.

name: Johnny Booker
comments: Americanized versions of this song have titles including "Jonny Boker", "Old Johnny Booker", "Mister Booger" "What Johnny Booker Wouldn't Do". The Caribbean shanty "Johnny Bowker" (also known as "Do My Jolly Boy") and the British song "Old Johnny Booger" are related to the American "Johnny Booker" song.  This widely disseminated song/tune is known as a banjo piece and stems from the minstrel era where it was called "Old Johnny Bigger," among other titles. Sheet music published around 1840 names the song as "Jonny Boker or the Broken Yoke", "as sung by J. W. Sweeney" [Sweeney's Virginia Melodies]...

name: Lone Green Valley / The Jealous Lover / Pearl Bryan
comments: Traditional about a jealous lover who lures his sweetheart (sometimes named Pearl Bryan(t), sometimes Florella) down into the valley and plunges a knife into her and kills her.  The storyline follows the same one found in Pretty Polly and arguably this could be considered as a variant that doesn't warrant adaptation status. [Verse One of the Lone Green Valley variant] Way down in a lone green valley down where the roses bloom and fade, There was a jealous lover in love with a beautiful maid.
adapted_from: Pretty Polly written by [Traditional]

name: Lord Lovel
comments: aka "Lord Lovell" or "Lord Lovat" [Roud 48; Child 75; G/D 6:1232; Ballad Index C075; VWML AW/6/103, CC/1/147; Bodleian Roud 48; Wiltshire 879, 880; Mudcat 150785; trad.] The earliest documented version of this tragic ballad is "The Ballad of Lady Hounsibelle and Lord Lovel" in Horace Walpole's letter to Rev. Thomas Percy on 5 February 1765. According to F.J. Child the ballad is made up of several earlier ones including Lord Thomas and Fair Eleanor (Child 73), Lady Maisry (Child 65), Death and the Lady, and Barbara Allen (Child 84).

name: Prayer of a Miner's Child
comments: Song about a child praying that his/her coal miner father be safe in the mines and steadily employed. It begins "He's just an old coal miner, Lord that's all he's ever been, He's worked his life away in mines with all the other men..". Teenager Shirley Hill published this song in a United Mine Worker's journal in the mid-1960s.  Dock Boggs found it and wrote to Hill asking for permission to make it into a song and he recorded it in July 1966. There is a similar song called Dream of a Miner's Child , that is from the perspective of the child imploring his/her father not to go to the mines today because the child dreamt there would be a fire down in the mines and they would all die.

name: Bright Sunny South

comments: Comic song written by John F. Poole and published in 1866 by Frederick Blume of NYC. Description - The singer is stopped and made to pay a bill he never incurred, then beaten up for wronging a girl he does not know, and finally arrested and convicted for a crime he didn't commit. Only when the police find "the fellow that looks like me" is he freed.  First recorded in 1927 by both Charlie Newman and Al Hopkins and His Bucklebusters (i.e. The Hill Billies). The tune used in the song is similar to the one in the fiddle tune, Over the Waterfall

name: St. Anne's Reel
comments: Reel tune originating in Canada that quickly spread to America and Ireland. The Americanized name is "St. Anne's Reel".  First recorded by Montreal fiddler Willie Ringuette as "Quadrille du loup garou - 4ème partie" (1927), followed by Montreal fiddler, Joseph Allard (1873-1947), as "Reel des esquimaults" (1930). It was popularized by radio and TV personality Don Messer in the 1940s and his rendition spread to America and the British Isles (particularly in Ireland).

name: Billy Richardson's Last Ride
comments: Another train wreck song involving the C & O Railway. This one commemorates the death of a locomotive engineer in the Kanawha Valley of West Virginia. Billy Richardson, an engineer on the Chesapeake & Ohio Railroad from 1878 to 1910, was known to run fast and on time. People along the C & O recalled that Richardson would wave and whistle as his train sped by.  The affable engineer developed a habit of leaning far out of the right cab window. Richardson’s usual run was from Hinton to Huntington and back. On December 14, 1910, he was running west toward Huntington. Passing through Scary, near St. Albans, Richardson blew the whistle and stuck his head out the window to look back. The mail crane, a track-side device from which trains snatched mail bags on the fly, struck Billy Richardson in the head. The fireman, Cecil Lively, brought the train into Huntington on time. Richardson died shortly after reaching the hospital there. In 1926, a train engineer with the Norfolk & Western named Cleburne Meeks, who as a boy stood in his backyard every other day to wave at Billy Richardson, wrote the song lyrics to ‘‘Billy Richardson’s Last Ride.’’ He sent them to Carson J. Robison, and Robison composed the tune. Vernon Dalhart immediately recorded it in June 1926 for an astonishing seven different record companies.

Of the several extant versions of the carol, the one most usually performed today is based on a version published in 1521 in Wynkyn de Worde's Christmasse Carolles.

name: The Wreck of the C & O No. 5
comments: Another train wreck song based on actual events involving the Chesapeake & Ohio (C & O) Railway. The tragedy occurred on October 6, 1920 and it involved the luxury passenger train known as the Sportsman, which ran daily between Cincinnati and Washington D.C. The train derailed and an engineer named Dolly Womack was burned to death. This song begins "From Washington to Charlottesville then Staunton on the line..." Cleburne C. Meeks this song and Carson Robison composed the music. They had previously collaborated on Meeks' other train song, Billy Richardson's Last Ride . Note: This song is similar to the much more well known song, The Wreck on the C & O (but it involved a different train wreck).

name: The Wreck of the C & O Sportsman
comments: Another train wreck song involving the C & O Railway.  This wreck occurred in West Virginia on June 21, 1930, three months after their new "Sportsman" train debuted. The tragedy was memorialized in the coming year by Bernice "Si" Coleman, a former railroad employee who was by then a fiddler and also a recording artist who made a number of recordings in 1931 with Ernest Branch (as Branch and Coleman).  Coleman and his band recorded his song on June 4, 1931, for the Starr Piano Company and it was issued on the chain store budget label Superior in August 1931 attributed to "John Martin". Roy Harvey , of earlier The North Carolina Ramblers fame, was the singer on the recording, so the "John Martin" recording artist pseudonymn is associated with Harvey rather than Coleman or the full band.  For simplification SHS is also assigning the Superior release to Harvey. Song begins - Far away on the banks of New River, Wwhile the deep the deep shades of twilight hung low In the mountains of ol' West Virginia On the line of the old C & O

name: My Pretty Quadroon
comments: A song titled, "My Pretty Quadroon," with words and music by Mary Dodge was published in 1863. In 1930 Nat Vincent and Fred Howard wrote a different song with the same title that was loosely influenced by the Mary Dodge song. This new song was recorded by the Beverly Hill Billies in April 1930. During their performances, this group described the song as "400 years old, said to have been written in the days when the Spanish galleons sailed the seas." This was show biz hype and not an accurate history of the song.

name: Annie Dear I'm Called Away
comments: Victorian song written by British lyricist Harry Hunter (1841-1906) and British composer John Guest for the Manhattan Minstrels, who performed at the British music halls and minstrel shows. Hunter was part of that performing troupe.  It was also known as "I'm Called Away" or "Annie Dear".  The song was being performed in U.S. minstrel shows by the 1880s.  In 1885, American composer C.B. Coolidge arranged the song by changing the chorus from "Goodbye Annie Goodbye Darling" to Goodbye Maggie, Goodbye Darling" and shortened the song title to "Called Away". Song begins "By a cottage in the twilight stands a soldier and a maid, Solemn words are being spoken for his country needs his aid..."

name: The Lincolnshire Poacher
comments: "The Lincolnshire Poacher" is a traditional English folk song associated with the county of Lincolnshire, and deals with the joys of poaching. It is considered to be the unofficial county anthem of Lincolnshire. It is catalogued as Roud Folk Song Index No. 299.

name: The Soldier and the Sailor
comments: Variants of this song can be found throughout the United Kingdom, but once again also in Canada. Variants in the text allow for colloquialisms in accordance to the county or indeed country they are being performed in. In more landlocked areas the soldier is the primary character, however in more seabound areas it is the sailor who is the protagonist. aka "The Topman and the Afterguard" [Roud 350; G/D 3:685; Ballad Index Doe277; Wiltshire 472; trad.] First published in 1874 (as "Soldier's Amen") in "Allan's Lone Star Ballads", compiled by Francis D. Allen.

name: Key to the Kingdom
comments: Traditional African-American gospel spiritual. There are many songs with similar titles and some with the same refrain as this one but considerably different lyrics beyond that. This is the Bessie Johnson version recorded March 1929.  For example, Josh White recorded a 1935 song called "Got a Key to the Kingdom" (Melotone 5 11 60) with the identical refrain but different from there.  Washington Phillips recorded his song in December 1929, 'I've Got the Key to the Kingdom" (Columbia 14511) that also shares the same refrain (except he says "The Devil can't do me no harm"), but his lyrics are completely different thereafter. [Opening verse and chorus] I've got the keys to the kingdom, The world can't do me no harm. (repeat) Go Gabriel, get the trumpet, Move on down to the sea, Don't you sound that trumpet, Till you hear from me

name: Swannanoa Tunnel
comments: The work song "Swannanoa Tunnel" is well known in the Appalachian mountains and was collected by folklorist Cecil Sharp in 1916. Western North Carolina Railroad's Swannanoa Tunnel was the longest (1800 feet) of seven hand-dug tunnels through the Blue Ridge mountains to Asheville. The project, completed in 1879, took twenty years and cost at least 300 lives.   The first recording was made on December 9, 1939 by Will "Shorty" Love under the title "Asheville Junction." It can be heard HERE . Bascom Lamar Lunsford's 1949 recording is the most well known and the song is most associated with him.

name: Evening Star Waltz
comments: "Evening Star Waltz" is the Americanized name for Lanner's Abend-Sterne Walzer, Op. 180 and was published in 1841.  The waltz tune known in the US as "Evening Star Waltz" became popular in the old-time genre as a fiddle tune, and can also be named "Evening Rainbow Waltz".

name: Wild Hog in the Woods
comments: Old-Time, breakdown fiddle tune first recorded by Lonesome Luke on February 12, 1931. The fiddle tune had the same name as "Wild Hog in the Woods" that is part of the "Sir Lionel / Old Bangum" family of songs and the fiddle tune started being performed with lyrics of the folk traditional (e.g., Fuzzy Mountain Stringband's 1972 song). Mainly Norfolk indicates Lonesome Luke's fiddle tune did evolve from the tune of the traditional, while Fresno State indicates the fiddle tune is unrelated. But again, when performed with lyrics they always are from the folk traditional. There's a wild hog in yonder woods, Diddle oh down, diddle oh day, There's a wild hog in yonder woods, Diddle oh down, oh day. There's a wild hog in yonder woods, He cuts your throat, and he drinks your blood, Cut him down, cut him down, kill him if you can.

name: Frankie Silvers
comments: Ballad based on true events and written from the perspective of the singer, Frankie Silvers, who has been condemned to die for murdering her husband. She describes the deed and its consequences with horror.  Opening line "This dreadful, dark, and dismal day has swept all my glories away."   Frankie was hanged on July 12, 1833 in Morganton, North Carolina, and the words to this song were purportedly printed out on leaflets and sold to the citizens attending the public lynching. It isn't known who wrote the song, but it's lore was personified when it was falsely alleged that Frankie sang these words as she was about to be executed. The lyrics were printed in the Morganton newspaper in 1886.  Byrd Moore and His Hot Shots (featuring Clarence Ashley on lead vocals) first recorded this song on October 23, 1929 at the historic Johnson City, Tennessee sessions.

name: The Old Arm Chair
comments: aka "Granny's Old Arm Chair".  Comedic song about a man's grandmother dying at the age of 83 and only leaving him this "old arm chair".  His siblings scorned him for it, but at the end of the song the chair broke and inside it he found lots of money his grandmother had stashed away for him, so he got the last laugh telling them "don't you wish you had the old arm chair". The authorship is uncertain. In 1880, two songs with identical lyrics were published in NYC, one by Frank B. Carr (no info. available) as "Grandma's Old Arm-Chair" and one by John Read (who had published other songs around the same time frame) as "Grandmother's Chair". So, Read is the more likely author of the two.  Interestingly, the song references "pounds" (i.e., British money) instead of "dollars", which would imply a Brit might have written the song.  Some actually attribute this to the British poet Eliza Cook and the tune to Henry Russell. Cook published a poem in 1840 called "The Old Arm Chair" but the words to it have no relation to the ones in this song. Given all the uncertainty, SHS is assigning "Unknown" for the songwriting credits and naming the song based off the apparent first 1927 releases that were titled "The Old Arm Chair".

name: Three Jolly Huntsmen / Three Men Went A-Hunting / Three Drunken Huntsmen
comments: There are several families of related songs originating from the British Isles involving three men who went hunting (or sporting).  Mainly Norfolk has one group it has labeled "Three Jolly Huntsmen / Three Jolly Sportsmen" [Roud 796, Ballad Index R076] involving three men who went out on a fox hunt. They also have a group labeled "Three Drunken Huntsmen / Three Men Went A-Hunting / Six Jovial Welshmen" [Roud 283, Ballad Index R077] that usually involve three men from different countries unsuccessfully hunting who end up drinking and naming the things they think they have espied (e.g., a porcupine, barn, frog, moon).  However, many performances have become intertwined.  For example, Fresno State contradicts Mainly Norfolk and says the Ballad index includes the American variant "Three Men Went A-Hunting" songs with the Three Jolly Huntsmen (not Three Drunken Huntsmen), as it doesn't deal with drinking but it does deal with men from three different countries naming the things they have seen. Cyril Tawney's "The Three Huntsmen" also doesn't involve getting drunk and the like but Mainly Norfolk has it classified there.  SHS is just going to combine the entire grouping of songs at present until more definitive precision can be made. There is also another group of traditionals involving Three Jolly Rogues
